title: Quarto Test Slides
text: Second Slide

title: Estimating the Hubble Constant with Type Ia Supernovae
text:
#| label: load-packages #| include: false
import pandas as pd import numpy as np import matplotlib.pyplot as plt import seaborn as sns
from sklearn.linear_model import LinearRegression from sklearn.preprocessing import PolynomialFeatures from sklearn.metrics import mean_squared_error, mean_absolute_error, r2_score
sns.set_theme(style=“whitegrid”) sns.set_context(“notebook”, font_scale=1.1)
plt.rcParams[‘figure.dpi’] = 300 plt.rcParams[‘savefig.dpi’] = 300 plt.rcParams[‘figure.figsize’] = (6, 6 * 0.618)
#| label: load-data #| include: false
df = pd.read_csv(“../data/processed/clean_sn_data.csv”)
X = df[[‘d_L_Mpc’]].values y = df[‘velocity_kms’].values

Linear model (global)
lin_model = LinearRegression() lin_model.fit(X, y) y_pred = lin_model.predict(X)
rmse_lin = np.sqrt(mean_squared_error(y, y_pred)) mae_lin = mean_absolute_error(y, y_pred) r2_lin = r2_score(y, y_pred)


Quadratic model (curvature test)
poly = PolynomialFeatures(degree=2, include_bias=False) X_poly = poly.fit_transform(X)
poly_model = LinearRegression() poly_model.fit(X_poly, y) y_poly_pred = poly_model.predict(X_poly)
rmse_poly = np.sqrt(mean_squared_error(y, y_poly_pred)) mae_poly = mean_absolute_error(y, y_poly_pred)

title: Estimating the Hubble Constant with Pantheon+ Supernovae
text:
Goal
-## Research Question

What functional form best describes the relationship between distance and recession velocity?
How does a simple linear model compare to more flexible models?
Estimate the Hubble constant (H₀) using Pantheon+ supernova data
Evaluate whether a simple linear Hubble Law fits well

title: Estimating the Hubble Constant with Pantheon+ Supernovae
text:
Data




Dataset: Pantheon+ supernovae (distance vs recessional velocity)
Pantheon+ provides high-quality Type Ia supernova distances
Focus on low-redshift regime where Hubble’s Law applies






Quantity
Value




Total supernovae (n)
~1700


Low-z subset (zHD < 0.1)
645


Velocity range (km/s)
~300 – 40,000


Luminosity distance range (Mpc)
~1 – 1,600


Redshift zHD range
~0.001 – 0.23

title: Estimating the Hubble Constant with Pantheon+ Supernovae
text:
Approach


Baseline model: linear regression (v = H₀ d)

Theory predicts proportional increase of velocity with distance
Slope provides an estimate of the Hubble constant

Check fit: residual patterns vs distance
Compare: linear vs quadratic (diagnostic; not expected physically at low z)

Linear model: R² = 0.983, RMSE = 711 km/s
Estimated H₀ = 64 km/s/Mpc

title: Estimating the Hubble Constant with Pantheon+ Supernovae
text:
Hubble Diagram


Strong linear relationship between distance and velocity
Scatter increases at larger distances

title: Estimating the Hubble Constant with Pantheon+ Supernovae
text:
Model Performance


Linear model fit:

R² ≈ 0.98
RMSE ≈ 711 km/s

Estimated Hubble constant:

H₀ ≈ 65–67 km/s/Mpc

MAE low, indicating generally accurate predictions
High R² shows linear trend explains most variance




Strong linear relationship between distance and velocity
Scatter increases at larger distances

title: Estimating the Hubble Constant with Pantheon+ Supernovae
text:
Residuals & Interpretation

Residuals increase slightly with distance
Pattern suggests growing observational uncertainty at large distances
No strong evidence that a nonlinear model is required

title: Estimating the Hubble Constant with Pantheon+ Supernovae
text:
Main Takeaway

Hubble’s Law provides an excellent first-order description of the data
Linear regression yields a stable estimate of H₀
More complex models do not improve performance for this dataset

title: Estimating the Hubble Constant with Pantheon+ Supernovae
text:
Goal / Research Question

What functional form best describes the relationship between distance and recession velocity?
How does a simple linear model compare to more flexible models?
Estimate the Hubble constant (H0) using supernova data
Evaluate whether a linear Hubble Law fits the data well

title: Estimating the Hubble Constant with Pantheon+ Supernovae
text:
Linear Model


Theory predicts proportional increase of velocity with distance
Linear regression used to quantify this relationship
Slope provides an estimate of H₀

title: Estimating the Hubble Constant with Pantheon+ Supernovae
text:
Linear Model Performance




R² ≈ 0.98
RMSE ≈ 711 km/s
MAE ≈ 492 km/s
Slope provides an estimate of H₀

title: Estimating the Hubble Constant with Pantheon+ Supernovae
text:
Residual Analysis




Residuals mostly random at shorter distances
Slight trend appears only at largest distances
Suggests local deviations rather than global nonlinearity

title: Estimating the Hubble Constant with Pantheon+ Supernovae
text:
Quadratic Model Test


Quadratic regression used to test for curvature
If curvature were meaningful, performance should improve
Model performed significantly worse (higher RMSE)

title: Estimating the Hubble Constant with Pantheon+ Supernovae
text:
Model Comparison

Linear model RMSE ≈ 711 km/s
Quadratic model RMSE ≈ 7604 km/s
Added complexity increases error rather than improving fit

title: Estimating the Hubble Constant with Pantheon+ Supernovae
text:
Interpretation




Strong positive distance–velocity relationship observed
Linear model captures dominant physical trend
Deviations at large distances likely due to observational uncertainty

title: Estimating the Hubble Constant with Pantheon+ Supernovae
text:
Limitations


Analysis focused on low-redshift supernovae
Measurement uncertainty increases at large distances
More complex cosmological models not explored

title: Estimating the Hubble Constant with Pantheon+ Supernovae
text:
Conclusion

Linear regression provides a strong fit to low-redshift Pantheon+ supernova data

Estimated Hubble constant:
(H_0  )

Residuals show increasing uncertainty at larger redshifts, but no evidence that added complexity improves the model

For the local universe, a linear Hubble Law remains an effective and interpretable model

title: Estimating the Hubble Constant with Pantheon+ Supernovae
text:
Redshift Split Results

Low-redshift subset

n = 645
Slope ≈ 66.8 km/s/Mpc
RMSE ≈ 534 km/s
Stable and consistent with global linear fit

High-redshift subset

n = 1056
Slope ≈ 23.2 km/s/Mpc
RMSE ≈ 16,137 km/s
Unstable, dominated by measurement uncertainty

title: Estimating the Hubble Constant with Pantheon+ Supernovae
text: Redshift vs Velocity

title: Estimating the Hubble Constant with Pantheon+ Supernovae
text:
Residuals by Redshift



Residual variance increases with redshift

Indicates non-constant error (heteroskedasticity)

Expected due to growing distance uncertainty and reduced dominance of peculiar velocities

Implication:
Linear trend remains valid, but error structure suggests weighted modeling for future work.

title: Estimating the Hubble Constant with Pantheon+ Supernovae
text:
Trend / Smoothing Check

Apparent curvature is localized to high redshift
Visual smoothing does not improve predictive performance



Large residuals at high distance are not evidence of nonlinear expansion
Errors increase with redshift due to observational uncertainty
Global linear Hubble model remains appropriate for this dataset

title: Estimating the Hubble Constant with Pantheon+ Supernovae
text:
Motivation & Research Question

Pantheon+ provides high-quality Type Ia supernova distances
Ideal for estimating the Hubble constant at low redshift
What functional form best describes distance–velocity?

title: Estimating the Hubble Constant with Pantheon+ Supernovae
text:
Modeling Approach

Expect linear relationship at low redshift (Hubble’s Law)
Linear regression used as baseline model
Quadratic model tested only as a diagnostic for curvature

title: Estimating the Hubble Constant with Pantheon+ Supernovae
text:
Residuals & Redshift Test




Residuals are mostly random at low distance / low redshift
Scatter increases primarily at highest redshift
Data split into two regimes:

Low-z: stable slope, low RMSE
High-z: unstable fit, noise-dominated

Indicates measurement uncertainty, not nonlinear expansion

Hubble Diagram

Linear Model Performance

High-z: unstable, noise-dominated

title: Estimating the Hubble Constant with Pantheon+ Supernovae
text:
Data . {smaller}

Dataset: Pantheon+ supernovae (distance vs recessional velocity)
Pantheon+ provides high-quality Type Ia supernova distances
Focus on low-redshift regime where Hubble’s Law applies
Key variables: distance and velocity (after cleaning)

title: Project Title
section: Exploratory Data Analysis: Distance vs Velocity
text:
Exploratory Data Analysis: Distance vs Velocity



Strong positive relationship: velocity increases with distance
Overall trend appears approximately linear
Scatter increases at larger distances (possible heteroskedasticity)
:::


Interpretation

Supports the expected Hubble Law pattern
Motivates checking residuals for systematic structure
:::


Residual Check (EDA)

Residuals are mostly centered near 0
Slight pattern at larger distances (mild curvature in smoothed trend)
Could reflect:

measurement noise growing with distance
physical departures from strict linearity (even at low z)




Baseline Model: Linear Regression
Model
[ v = H_0 d + b]

Estimated (H_0 ) km/s/Mpc
Intercept (b ) km/s (consistent with local/peculiar motions)
Strong fit:

(R^2 )
RMSE () km/s




Model Comparison: Quadratic Regression
Model
[ v = ad^2 + bd + c]

Performed much worse than linear:

RMSE increased to ~7600 km/s

Indicates overfitting / unnecessary flexibility
Conclusion: curvature term hurts prediction rather than improving it



Why Might Small Curvature Appear?

Distance in cosmology is not perfectly linear with redshift: [ d_L = (1 + z) r(z)]
Even at low redshift, small departures can appear in residuals
Data science takeaway:

Residual patterns can reflect real structure
But added complexity must be justified by metrics + theory




Model Justification (Data Science Framing)
Why linear is the best choice here

Best predictive performance (lower RMSE)
High interpretability: slope directly estimates (H_0)
Aligns with theory in low-z regime

Why quadratic is not supported

Worse out-of-sample behavior (overfit signal/noise)
No strong physical justification at z < 0.1



Limitations & Future Work
Limitations

Low-redshift only (local universe)
No full uncertainty propagation / weighting
Assumes independent errors

Future extensions

Weighted regression (uncertainty-aware)
Split by redshift threshold and compare slopes
Bayesian regression for posterior on (H_0)
Extend to higher redshift with cosmology-aware models



Key Takeaways

A simple linear model can be both accurate and interpretable
EDA + residuals guide whether complexity is warranted
Quadratic model increased error → clear overfitting signal
Final estimate (low-z): (H_0 ) km/s/Mpc

title: Estimating the Hubble Constant with Pantheon+ Supernovae
text:
Model Interpretation & Justification

Interpretation - Linear slope directly estimates the Hubble constant:
(H_0  ) - Intercept reflects local velocity effects and calibration offsets
Justification - Linear model captures the dominant trend with minimal complexity - Quadratic model offers only marginal metric gains - Added flexibility reduces interpretability and lacks physical motivation at low redshift
Final choice - Linear regression provides the best balance of performance, interpretability, and theory

title: Estimating the Hubble Constant with Pantheon+ Supernovae
text:
Low-Redshift Focus (zHD < 0.1)



This subset is where Hubble’s Law is expected to be closest to linear

Reduced cosmological curvature effects compared to higher redshift

Used to estimate (H_0) with better interpretability


(If you computed a low-z slope separately, add it here:)
- (H_0) (low-z): [insert your value] km/s/Mpc

title: Estimating the Hubble Constant with Pantheon+ Supernovae
text:
Higher-Redshift Behavior (Context)


At higher redshift, residual variance increases noticeably

Linear trend remains present, but uncertainty grows

Slope estimates become less stable due to:

increasing distance uncertainty

cosmological effects beyond linear expansion


Implication - Higher-redshift data motivate cosmology-aware models
- Do not justify adding polynomial terms to the low-z model

title: Estimating the Hubble Constant with Pantheon+ Supernovae
text:
Low-Redshift Model (zHD < 0.1)


Analysis restricted to the low-redshift regime where Hubble’s Law is expected to be linear

Linear regression fit is tighter than for the full dataset

Estimated slope (Hubble constant):
(H_0  )

Interpretation - Reduced scatter confirms linear behavior in the local universe
- Supports using a simple linear model to estimate (H_0)

title: Estimating the Hubble Constant with Pantheon+ Supernovae
text:
Higher-Redshift Behavior (Context)


At higher redshift, residual variance increases substantially

Linear trend is still present, but uncertainty grows

Slope estimates become less stable due to:

increasing distance uncertainty

cosmological effects beyond simple linear expansion


Implication - Higher redshift data are better suited for cosmology-aware models
- Do not justify adding polynomial terms in the low-z regime
